questions.text: All of the following mechanisms might account for a reduce-risk of upper genital tract infection in users of progestin-releasing IUDs, except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decreased ovulation Mechanisms account for a potentially reduced risk of upper-genital-tract infection in users of progestin-releasing IUDs . The effect of progestin on cervical mucus makes it thick and relatively impenetrable to bacteria. Since uterine bleeding is greatly decreased in users of the LNG-IUD (progestin-releasing IUD), any retrograde menstruation (which might seed the fallopian tubes with bacteria) should be reduced as well. Plus decidual changes in the endometrium may make it less susceptible to infection. In other words, progestin-releasing IUDs may mimic the protective effect of combined oral contraceptives and depot medroxyprogesterone acetate against upper-genital-tract infection. PID is common in non-hormonal IUCD-related bacterial infections are due to contamination of the endometrial cavity at the time of insertion . Actinomycosis infection is related to IUCD use. The most common side effect of IUCDs is increased vaginal bleeding.

Highyeild:

IUDs: First-generation IUDs: These are inert or non-medicated devices. g. Lippe’s loop. Second-generation IUDs : It consists of copper or silver-containing IUDs e.g. Cu T 200 , Cu T 380- Ag , Nova T , Multiload Cu 375 . Third generation IUDs ; This consists of hormone-releasing E.g. Progestasert , Mirena , LNG 20 . Commonly used IUD Lippe s Loop

Extraedge:

Mechanism of Action of IUCD Non medicated IUCD Cu containing IUCD Progestin releasing IUCD • Act as a foreign body in the uterus and produces a sterile inflammation and tissue injury of a minor degree sufficient enough to be spermicidal . therefore prevent both intra-uterine and ectopic pregnancy. • It provokes uterine contractility & increases tubal peristalsis. • Elute copper which bring about enzymatic and metabolic changes in the endometrial tissue & also produce changes in cervical mucus and endometrial secretions. • They cause decidualization with atrophy of endometrial glands and therefore inhibit implantation. • Alter cervical Mucus causing inhibition of sperm penetration and capacitation. • In 40% of cases ovulation is also inhibited. e.g. Lippe’s loop. e.g. Cu T 380- Ag, Nova T, Multiload 375 E.g. Progestasert,Mirena ,LNG 20

questions.text: The progesterone component of OCP acts by:

options.label: C
options.text: Bringing about alterations in cervical mucus

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Actions of the progesterone component of combined oral contraceptives: Suppresses ovulation by its inhibitory action on the pituitary and the hypothalamus. This is predominantly achieved by estrogens but even by progesterone. Causes Atrophic changes in the endometrium and prevents nidation even if fertilization occurs. Acts on the cervical mucus , making it thick, and tenacious and impenetrable by sperms.

Extraedge:

The third-generation progestogen has a higher affinity for progesterone receptors and has a role in inhibiting ovulation. The main function of progestogen in combined pills is, to counteract the undesirable effects of estrogen such as endometrial hyperplasia and heavy withdrawal bleeding.

Solution:

Irregular vaginal bleeding may be a side effect

Highyeild:

POP is devoid of any estrogen compound. It contains a very low dose of progestin in any one of the following form-Levonorgestrel 75 µg, norethisterone 350 µg, desogestrel 75 µg, lynestrenol 500 µg or norgestrel 30 ug. It has to be taken daily from the first day of the cycle. Mechanism of action: It works mainly by making cervical mucus thick and viscous, thereby preventing sperm penetration. The endometrium becomes atrophic, so blastocyst implantation is also hindered. In about 2 percent of cases, ovulation is inhibited and 50 percent women ovulate normally. How to prescribe a mini pill: The first pill has to be taken on the first day of the cycle and then continuously. It has to be taken regularly and at the same time of the day. There must be no break between the packs. Delay in intake for more than 3 hours, the woman should have missed the pill immediately and the next one as scheduled. Extra precaution has to be taken for the next 2 days (see above). Advantages: Side effects attributed to estrogen in the combined pill are totally eliminated No adverse effect on lactation and hence can be suitably prescribed in lactating women and as such it is often called a "Lactation Pill" Easy to take as there is no "On and Off" regime It may be prescribed in patients having (medical disorders) hypertension, fibroid, diabetes, epilepsy, smoking, and a history of thromboembolism Reduces the risk of PID and endometrial cancer. Disadvantages: There may be acne, mastalgia, headache, breakthrough bleeding, or at times amenorrhea in about 20-30 percent of cases All the side effects, attributed to progestins may be evident Simple cysts of the ovary may be seen, but they do not require any surgery The failure rate is about Contraindications: Pregnancy unexplained vaginal bleeding recent breast cancer arterial disease. thromboembolic disease. Main side effects of Minipill /progesterone-only pill: Irregular bleeding and amenorrhea

questions.correct_answer: C. Has a history of ectopic pregnancy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Has a history of ectopic pregnancy Options A, B, and D are ideal candidates for IUCD Ideal IUCD candidate as a woman. Who has no history of pelvic disease. Who has born at least one child Has normal menstrual periods Is willing to check IUCD tail Has access to follow-up and treatment of potential problems Is in a monogamous relationship.

Highyeild:

Some important points from ‘Leon Speroff’ on patient selection for IUD. The risk factors for STIs (sexually transmitted infections) are the most important considerations Women who are on anticoagulants or have bleeding disorder or with heavy menstrual periods are not good candidates for copper IUCD but might benefit from progestin IUCD. Women who have abnormalities of the uterus like bicornuate uterus are not good candidates for IUD insertion. Immunosuppressed individuals should not use IUCD. Patients at risk for endocarditis should be treated with prophylactic antibiotics at the insertion and removal of IUCD. Cervical dysplasia is not a contraindication for the use of IUCD but in patients with cervical stenosis, it may be difficult to insert IUCD. Cu-containing IUCD can be the ideal choice for a woman with diabetes especially if vascular disease is present.

Extraedge:

Contraindications for Insertion of IUCD: (1) Presence of pelvic infection current or within 3 months; (2) Undiagnosed genital tract bleeding; (3) Suspected pregnancy; (4) Distortion of the shape of the uterine cavity as in fibroid or congenital uterine-malformation; (5) Severe dysmenorrhea; (6) Past history of ectopic pregnancy; (7) Within 6 weeks following cesarean section; (8) STIs Current or within 3 months; (9) Trophoblastic disease; (10) Significant immunosuppression. Additionally for CuT are: (11) Wilson disease and (12) Copper allergy. For LNG-IUS are: (13) Hepatic tumor or hepatocellular disease (active); (14) Current breast cancer and (15) Severe arterial disease.

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: C. Remove the IUD to decrease the risk of infection
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Remove the IUD to decrease the risk of infection Removing the IUD to decrease the risk of infection is the most appropriate course of action.

Highyeild:

A woman with an IUCD in place , with amenorrhea should have a pregnancy test and pelvic examination . An intrauterine pregnancy can occur and continue successfully to term with an IUCD in place. Possibility 1-If an intrauterine pregnancy is diagnosed and IUCD strings are visible: IUCD should be removed as soon as possible in order to prevent septic abortion , premature rupture of membranes, and premature birth. Also, do an USG to know whether it is intrauterine or ectopic pregnancy. Possibility 2-If an intrauterine pregnancy is diagnosed and IUCD strings are not visible: An ultrasound e xamination should be performed to localize the IUCD and determine whether expulsion has occurred. If the IUCD is present there are 3 options for management. Therapeutic abortion If IUCD is not fundal in the location: ultrasound-guided intrauterine removal of IUCD. If IUCD is present in the fundus of the uterus : it should be left in place and pregnancy continued with the device left in place. If the pregnancy continues with the device in place, the patient should be warned of the symptoms of intrauterine infection like fever or flu-like symptoms, abdominal cramping, or bleeding. At the earliest sign of infection, high-dose intravenous antibiotic therapy should be given and the pregnancy evacuated promptly.

questions.text: A 28-year-old P1L1 had Cu T inserted 2 years back, on examination, Cu T threads are not seen. USG shows Cu T partly in the abdominal cavity. Method of removal is:

options.label: B
options.text: No need for removal (wait and watch)

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Laparoscopy Laparoscopy is the most appropriate method of removal here. When IUCD enters the abdominal cavity (partly or completely), laparoscopy is the preferred modality for retrieval. Sometimes due to dense adhesions around the Cu T, a laparotomy may be required to remove it.

Highyeild:

INDICATION FOR REMOVAL OF IUCD : Indications for removal: Persistent excessive regular or irregular uterine bleeding Flaring up of salpingitis Perforation of the uterus IUD has come out of place (partial expulsion) Pregnancy occurring with the device in situ Woman desirous of a baby Missing thread One year after menopause When the effective lifespan of the device is over. IUD removal is simple and can be done at any time. It is done by pulling the strings gently and slowly with forceps. METHOD OF REMOVAL OF IUD: Device inside the uterine cavity: It can be removed by any of the following methods mentioned below: (i) Especially designed blunt hook (Fig. 37.41). (ii) Artery forceps (Fig. 37.28) (iii) Uterine curette (Fig. 37.13) (iv) Hysteroscopically under direct vision (Fig. 29.6). Outside the uterus but inside the abdominal cavity: (i) Laparoscopy (ii) Laparotomy (rarely).

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Progesterone only pill Progesterone only pill. Mechanism of action: It works mainly by making cervical mucus thick and viscous , thereby preventing sperm penetration. The endometrium becomes atrophic, so blastocyst implantation is also hindered. POPs are safe with breastfeeding and very effective. They were mainly designed especially for lactating mothers.

In Breastfeeding Females For lactating mother s, contraceptives should be chosen in such a way that in addition to providing effective contraception, they do not adversely affect the success of lactation or the health of the infant. Barriers have a high failure rate of 4–14% and are not reliable for long-term control. As estrogens decrease the quality and quantity of milk , OCP pills are absolutely contraindicated in lactating mothers. POPs are safe with breastfeeding and very effective. They were mainly designed especially for lactating Progesterone only pill. Mechanism of action: It works mainly by making cervical mucus thick and viscous , thereby preventing sperm penetration. The endometrium becomes atrophic, so blastocyst implantation is also hindered.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: In a couple who are living separately in two cities and meet only, occasionally contraception of choice is a barrier method . Condoms are suitable for use in old age for couples who have frequent coitus, during lactation, during holidays, and subjects who cannot tolerate OCP, or IUCD. Option B: For newly married couples oral contraceptive pill is the method of choice provided there are no contraindications.It has many non-contraceptive benefits along with effective contraception but affects the quantity of milk. Barrier and Natural methods have a high failure rate. Option C: Lactation Amenorrhea Method (LAM) Excessive secretion of prolactin, which controls lactation, inhibits the pituitary. Prolactin inhibits luteinizing hormone (LH) but has no effect on follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). However, it partially inhibits ovarian response to both of these gonadotropins. As a result, while the prolactin level remains high, the ovary produces little estrogen and no progesterone. Hence, ovulation and menstruation are affected. LAM is e ffective only till 6 months postpartum . Beyond this, it is not a reliable method. Even for 6 months, it is effective only if there is exclusive breastfeeding. If at any time in the first 6 months the menses starts, then it cannot be used as birth control.

Suited ideally for- Lactating women Sickle cell anemia (best contraceptive) Seizure disorder (raises seizure threshold)

questions.text: Contraceptive to be avoided in epilepsy:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

OCP Epilepsy/seizure disorder is a relative contraindication for the use of OCPs as antiepileptic drugs like Phenytoin, carbamazepine, and phenobarbitone induce the synthesis of liver enzyme thereby reducing the plasma levels of ethinyl estradiol in women on combined pills, thereby increasing the chances of contraceptive failure. So in epilepsy OCPs should be avoided. Options B, C, andD - can be used in Epilepsy patients.

Highyeild:

CONTRACEPTIVES IN EPILEPSY PATIENT Consideration should be given to methods that neither affect antiepileptic drug metabolism nor the methods affected by drugs. These include intrauterine contraception with copper IUD, or levonorgestrel-releasing IUD, long-acting progestin-only methods, barrier methods, and sterilization.
